DNS from Namecheap to Cloudflare on Github Pages

29 Aug 2015

Reading time ~2 minutes

Testing my website fausto.xyz on Google PageSpeed Insights, I’ve checked that first byte delivery it was a bit delayed, after identifying the problem, I have the idea of transfering the DNS for CloudFlare to solve the problem. So, what’s next is the analysis and the solution.

1. What is the problem?

In a rapid analysis, we could see that exists is a 0.6 second delay on the first request to the server, (DNS Lookup), also that exists a second request.

If we go deep in the analysis we see that the second request is a 302 redirect.

2. 302 Redirects

After a quick search on Google, I found an Analyzing the GitHub Pages Waterfall Chart article, where @helloanselm found that Github Pages redirects sites with a A DNS record configuration.

I’m using that configuration on Namecheap, that doesn’t support the ALIAS record, suggested on Setting up a custom domain with Pages.

My other post completes all the information about this subject. -> DNS configuration on GitHub Pages with Namecheap.

For knowing more about an ALIAS you could also read -> Why ALIAS-type DNS Records Break The Internet by @norbu09.

3. CloudFlare DNS configuration for GitHub Pages

After we get a free account, we have to add our website.

After CloudFlare import our DNS records, we have to delete the two A records, and replace for one CNAME that points for username.github.io.. Use @ to reference the root of the domain.

Now we should have two CNAME records.

After we modify the DNS records on CloudFlare, we have to transfer the DNS from Namecheap.

4. Transfering DNS from Namecheap to CloudFlare

We can start doing sign in on our Namecheap account, select the domain name, after that select the option Transfer DNS to Webhost. .

Don’t forget that the nameservers that I’ve used gail.ns.cloudflare.com and hugh.ns.cloudflare.com, could not be the nameservers that are assigned to your account by CloudFlare.

5. It works?

After some days with the new DNS configurations from CloudFlare, I could say that I’m happy with the result. The 302 redirect is vanish and first byte time delivery is kicking ass.

I don’t know the way that this affects my website on GitHub Pages, but I know that CloudFlare ships with a DDoS protection, so I only could see advantages.

If you want to know more about all kind of DNS records, you can find good information in this article-> Differences between the A, CNAME, ALIAS and URL records. by DNSimple
